newsitem.title: ITALY: Arianespace confident on transition to Ariane-5.
newsitem.headline: Arianespace confident on transition to Ariane-5.

text.p: Arianespace is seeking to rebuild the confidence of insurers and satellite operators after the spectacular explosion of its first Ariane-5 rocket last June.
"Arianespace still aims for 98.5 percent reliability," Brigitte Vienne, risk manager of Arianespace, which is owned by the European Space Agency, told insurers at a conference on Friday.
She said the company aimed to offer an uninterrupted launch service to satellite operators during the transition from the Ariane-4 rocket to the Ariane-5.
Vienne added that Arianespace is willing to place build orders for more Ariane-4 rockets if necessary, while issues surrounding the newer model are resolved.
The much hyped debut of Ariane-5 ended in shreds after the rocket shattered 40 seconds after its launch from French Guyana last June 4 in front of television audiences around the world.
The explosion was blamed on a defect in its positioning system. The launch was not insured.
However, Arianespace told the Venice conference of insurers, satellite operators and rival launch companies that it remained in sound health.

"Arianespace still has a very strong position. We had 19 orders in 1996 and retain our 50 percent share of the market," said Vienne, adding that there was a strong increase in demand, particularly from the Asia Pacific region.

Vienne also pointed to the expected gains from STARSEM, a joint venture owned 35 percent by Aerospatiale, 15 percent by Arianespace and 50 percent by Russian partner firms to market the Soyuz launch vehicle.
STARSEM will be targeted at the growing demand for launching small constellation satellites, she said.
